body: Jack Newfield, a journalist and author who brought Brooklyn moxie, sassy cynicism and often zealous partisanship to muckraking reporting on subjects from New York politics to boxing, died on Monday night at New York-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 66. The cause was kidney cancer that spread to his lungs, said Howard J. Rubenstein, a spokesman
title: Jack Newfield, 66, Proud Muckraker, Dies

body: Mookie Wilson has landed in Brooklyn, where he will be the manager of the Cyclones, the popular Class A affiliate that plays in Coney Island. Wilson, who said yesterday that he aspired to be a major league manager, was promoted after two years as manager of the Kingsport Mets of the rookie-level Appalachian League. He compiled a 57-75 record there.
title: BASEBALL: METS NOTEBOOK; Mookie Wilson in Brooklyn

body: Fennie May Williams, 57, changed her name to Najeeulluh Maydun in the 1970's, when she converted to Islam. You would think ''that if you change your name then you become anew, but that is not true.'' she said recently at the offices of the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, one of the seven agencies supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases
title: The Neediest Cases; 57, and Trying to Make Up For an Education Denied

body: A woman died yesterday after she was struck by two vehicles as she walked across West Fourth Street in Homecrest, the police said. Both drivers fled the scene. The pedestrian, Joann Ceglecki, 44, of 1810 West Fourth Street, was walking near her home at the intersection of Kings Highway when she was struck at 1:20 p.m., investigators said. She was
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: One Dead In Hit-And-Run

body: ROTHFELD--Murray, 91. Devoted husband of Anita Olshin Rothfeld; loving father of Alan and Laura, Philip and Barbara, Neil and Carol; cherished grandfather (Mur) of Rachel and Avi; dear brother, brother-in-law & uncle. Services 12 noon today, Midwood Chapel, Coney Island Avenue and Avenue M., Brooklyn.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths ROTHFELD, MURRAY

body: They went out late. It was ugly weather. Six below zero in the Brooklyn night. Wind took garbage into the air. A blizzard was in the forecast. It was Lincoln's Birthday, 2003, in Brighton Beach. Not a night for humankind, but the sisters, one 73 and the other 70, didn't get holidays off, didn't get snow days. In years of miserable low points, it
title: Lillian and Julia: A Twilight of Fear; Bowed by Age, Battered by an Addicted Nephew And Forced Into Begging and Despair

body: Hulda Rossini, who ran the Rossini Opera Workshop with her husband, Luigi, for 39 years, spent most of her time out of the spotlight. While her students sang and performed onstage or in the couple's Central Park West living room, Mrs. Rossini was usually off to the side at the piano, accompanying them. None of which is to suggest that her presence
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE; Requiem for a Teacher Who Made the Diva Dramatic

body: A 12-year-old boy was struck by a car while riding his bicycle in Brooklyn and critically injured last night, the police said. The boy, whose name was not released, was crossing Gerritsen Avenue near Florence Avenue in Gerritsen Beach at 6:25 p.m. when he was hit by a 1983 Toyota driven by Louis Pascarella, 37, of Gerritsen Beach, the police said.
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Boy Hit By Car

title: Paid Notice: Deaths FRIEDBERG, DAN

body: The recruiter from Bowdoin College, Erby Mitchell, was telling 11 seniors at his old high school, James Madison in Brooklyn, how he had struggled a decade earlier to find his way out of poverty to college. One of the barriers, he told them, was the SAT. ''I took the SAT four times,'' he said. The students, who had been paying close attention from
title: Back in His Old Brooklyn School, Selling Hope and a Chance to Apply to Bowdoin

body: Murray Schumach, a reporter who harvested rich stories from New York's neighborhoods and whose 48-year career at The New York Times also took him from the Orient to Hollywood, from the back rooms of City Hall to the gem-cutting sanctums of the diamond district, died on Saturday. He was 91 and died at his Manhattan apartment after a long illness,
title: Murray Schumach, Neighborhood Storyteller, Dies at 91

body: Murray Schumach, a reporter who harvested rich stories from New York's neighborhoods and whose 48-year career at The New York Times also took him from the Orient to Hollywood, from the back rooms of City Hall to the gem-cutting sanctums of the diamond district, died yesterday He was 91 and died at his Manhattan apartment after a long illness,

body: CRAIG RADIX still can't believe his luck. He wanted a nice house, but he didn't want to leave the Bronx. Long Island and New Jersey just didn't do it for him. In the end, he traded the slightly grittier surroundings of his old Castle Hill neighborhood for fresh sea breezes -- and the usual grim pigeons for brilliant red cardinals, honking geese and
title: LIVING IN/Clason Point, the Bronx; Change Wafts In Along the Bronx Waterfront

body: Sex Museum's Allure Is Finally Catching On Sex has been more of an attraction this year at Fifth Avenue and 27th Street in Manhattan than it was last year. Well, the Museum of Sex has, at any rate. The museum opened in a building at that corner in October 2002, saying its purpose was ''to preserve and present the history, evolution and cultural
title: FOLLOWING UP

author: Boris Fishman is the editor of ''Wild East: Stories From the Last Frontier,'' a collection of short stories about the former Soviet Union and post-Soviet Eastern Europe.
body: WHAT does it mean to be from a place that is no longer on the map? My homeland, the Soviet Union, disintegrated in late 1991, a scant three years after my family had managed to escape its anti-Semitism and lack of opportunity. As an immigrant in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, with a funny haircut and even funnier clothes, I tended to worry more about
title: THE NEXT WAVE; 'Where Is Home, If the Place You Come From No Longer Exists?'

body: Fadl Ibrahim Mohammed was nearly overcome on Friday as he visited Times Square for the first time, marveling at the soaring buildings and the flashing lights. He spent the rest of his afternoon worshiping at a mosque in Brooklyn and strolling along the tree-lined streets south of Prospect Park. Yet his first full day of freedom was not enough to
title: Darfur Strife Behind Them, Two Detainees Win Freedom

body: A 15-year-old girl who escaped from custody Monday morning has been rearrested, the police said yesterday. The girl had been arrested at her home in Coney Island by officers of the Brooklyn Juvenile Crime Squad on a warrant for marijuana possession. When the patrol car stopped about 8 a.m. on Beverley Road, in Kensington, to pick up a second youth,
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Escapee Is Rearrested

body: Maurice Cheeks of the Portland Trail Blazers is a coach who respects hometown sentimentality. His 19-year-old rookie point guard, Sebastian Telfair, returns to the New York metropolitan area tonight, to the area that celebrated him, to play against the Nets. Although Cheeks joked purposely within Telfair's earshot that ''heck, no'' he would not
title: PRO BASKETBALL; Playing Time for Telfair? Hold On a Minute

body: The baseball players at Samuel J. Tilden High School, desperate for a winner, say they only watch the Mets in games against the Yankees. The reverend from Brooklyn, who attended Tilden High more than 30 years ago, traverses the country to preach about equality, but rarely about baseball. And the retired basketball star from Brownsville, whose very
title: BASEBALL; The Pillar From the Block

body: Virginia Eden sat at her living room table, cane hooked over the arm of her chair, fingering the yellowing photographs of herself as a young woman. Each picture is from a time when her body moved as she wished, when it jitterbugged and danced the Latin Hustle, and swam in the Atlantic Ocean at Coney Island with her best friend, Annette Cappello.
title: The Neediest Cases; Maintaining Independence During Times of Ill Health

body: A woman was shot fatally yesterday morning in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn during an argument in what appeared to be a gambling and after-hours club, the police and witnesses said. The woman, Susan Boyce, 40, of 2105 70th Street in Bay Ridge, was shot about 6:48 a.m., at 1739 West Seventh Street in the 62nd Precinct, the police said. She was
title: Woman Is Killed by Gunfire at a Brooklyn Club

body: There is a type of man so enamored by the inner workings of a subway train that, at 2 a.m., he is happier tinkering with its moving parts than lying asleep in bed. He is the sort who will come out after dark, night after night, on his own time, to do the hard work that makes the subway run. At 11 o'clock this morning, the politicians and the
title: Moving Pretty Well for an 87-Year-Old; Vintage Train Rolls Again for Subway Centennial

body: John McNamara, who walked every street in the Bronx and recorded the often idiosyncratic history of each (yes, even Yznaga Place), died on Oct. 15 in the Bronx. He was 92. The cause was prostate cancer, his son, John, said. Mr. McNamara was known for wearing his many hats, from fedoras to United States Navy watch caps to oversize truck drivers'
title: John McNamara, Sage Of the Bronx, Dies at 92

body: It is a law of nature, as immutable as gravity, that where there are old subway trains, there will be old subway train fanatics. title: Taking a Train Back in Time (No Need for a MetroCard)

title: Woman Charged With Painting Swastikas Aimed at Ex-Husband

body: A Song in Its Heart Q. The office building at 1650 Broadway has a large red-on-yellow sign painted on its upper stories: ''1650 Broadway, the Best-Known Address in the Entertainment World.'' Why was it famous? A. Number 1650 was a powerhouse of Tin Pan Alley at a time when New York was the center of the country's songwriting talent. Irving Berlin
title: F.Y.I.

body: NEW YORK, ignored in the presidential race, has its own tussle going on -- not over candidates, but over City Hall's plans for a stadium and expanded convention center on Manhattan's far West Side. The two sides are fighting fiercely, with the pro-stadium forces saying the proposed complex would generate jobs, promote the city's economy, reclaim a
title: Metro Matters; Out of the Park, More Baseballs Than Benefits

body: A large group of Republican officials gathered in a Staten Island catering hall last week to endorse Alfred B. Curtis, the candidate for a State Senate seat that covers a portion of the island and part of Brooklyn. And one by one, as guests at the fund-raiser dined on calamari and ziti, the elected officials urged the crowd to work to ensure that
title: A Brooklyn-Staten Island Senate Seat Becomes a Battleground

body: OVER the summer I decided that I was going to bike to work. I had always been a weekend rider, going on epic loops through the city, for 30 or 40 miles in an afternoon. From the vantage point of a bike, the city presents itself as a savorable panorama passing by at a speed somewhere between the blur outside a car window and the plodding pace of
title: Spin City

body: Two Brooklyn high school students were arrested yesterday after they were caught wandering through the school with loaded guns, officials said. An education official said another student reported that one of the boys with the guns had made a threatening remark earlier in the day. The students, whose names were not released because they are minors,
title: 2 Students With Loaded Guns Are Arrested

Activist, bookseller, scholar, conversationalist, and affectionate friend of all who knew him. He will be missed by his family and neighbors in Brooklyn Heights and beyond. Survived by his beloved companion and comrade of 16
title: Paid Notice: Deaths RIBEIRO, LUDGERO

body: It was the coldest of cold cases. Twenty years had passed without an arrest in the killing of Officer Ronald S. Stapleton, who was found shot twice in the stomach with his own revolver, his right eye gouged out, in the parking lot of a Brooklyn bar in 1977. The police investigation had stalled; private detectives hired by his family were stymied,
title: FALSE WITNESS: A Lawyer's Deception; A Thin Blue Lie, Admitted at Last

body: The old Italian-American men in Carroll Park rise with old-men efforts from their plastic chairs to see over the low concrete wall into the narrow clay court where red and green balls bounce and roll and knock about. Their game taxes the same skills as any child's play, a lot of hand-eye coordination and a little strategy, but it is their game.
title: A Crossover Moment for an Old World Game; In a New Tournament and a City Bar, Boccie Gets a Makeover

author: Jerome Charyn is the author of 10 crime novels featuring a Jewish police commissioner, among them ''El Bronx,'' ''Citizen Sidel'' and four titles reissued as ''The Isaac Quartet.'' His latest novel, ''The Green Lantern: A Romance of Stalinist Russia,'' will be published this fall by Thunder's Mouth Press.
body: NEW AMSTERDAM, circa 1655. Asser Levy, a member of the first little colony of Jews that arrived from Brazil to escape religious persecution, petitions Peter Stuyvesant, the governor of the colony, for the right to join the local militia. In what proved to be one of the first ''official'' acts of anti-Semitism in America, Stuyvesant refused. An
title: Officer Reilly He's Not

body: WHILE you look for your home among the block-by-block aerial views in ''New York: The Photo Atlas,'' showing every square foot of the city as it existed on June 2 and June 6, 2003, you may find yourself thinking, If only they'd told me they were going to take my picture that day, I would have dressed a little better. Actually, the resolution is not
title: BLOCKS; A Bird's-Eye Atlas of the City, Ready for Its Close-Up

body: The former boyfriend of a woman who was dating another man burst into a home in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn yesterday and shot and killed the man and the man's 73-year-old father, the police said. He then fled to a nearby schoolyard and turned the rifle on himself, the authorities said. The violence began at 10:40 a.m., the police said, when
title: Jealous Former Boyfriend Kills 2 Men, Then Turns Gun on Himself, Police Say

body: The signs, bright yellow, pink, blue and white and adorned with smiley faces, first appeared in couple of weeks ago, offering an odd mixture of cheer and menace. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE; Does Big Brother Use a Pooper-Scooper?

body: There was no major blackout, but then there was no unbearable sweaty stretch, either; no 100-degree sweltering front to linger like a purplish haze over Manhattan, causing a run on air-conditioners and a mass exodus to the shore. That suffocating August heat, or rather the lack thereof, made this summer a catch-as-catch-can for beach economies in
title: Uneventful Summer by the Shore Gets Mixed Reviews

title: AFTER THE CONVENTION: DEMONSTRATIONS; Police and Protesters Spar A Last Time, Over the Peace

title: FAMILY FARE

body: Larry Desmedt, a New York-based custom motorcycle builder and biker better known nationally as Indian Larry, died on Monday in Charlotte, N.C., of injuries he suffered doing a stunt on Saturday at an appearance there. He was 55 and lived in the East Village. His death was announced by Timothy White, a photographer and friend. He said Mr. Desmedt
title: Indian Larry, 55, Motorcycle Builder and Stunt Rider

body: AGAIN to a secret city place: the easternmost, uppermost deck of Pier 17 at the South Street Seaport in Lower Manhattan, a sanctuary in the midst of tourists, where lounge chairs bolted to the floorboards all but demand that you pause for a while and consider. Across the East River, a corner piece of the Brooklyn jigsaw offers its tree-shadowed
title: NEW YORK 2004; Who Can Claim to Know A City of 8 Million?

body: CONVENTIONEERS, already booked into dozens of events, have been inundated with official advice about what to visit in New York. title: NEW YORK 2004: NAVIGATING NEW YORK/WHAT TO SEE; City to Republicans: See This. Telling the Delegates Where to Go

title: CITY LORE; Fortress New York

title: A Cool Summer Can Mean a Chill on Business, Too

body: THE little airplane bobs and dips and yaws in the thermals rising around the southern tip of Flatbush Avenue; you can feel the warm air lifting the riveted aluminum wings. title: Sky Above, Hubbub Below

title: CONEY ISLAND; Funkytown Has a Boardwalk

body: It was the bottom of the ninth of a scoreless game under a canopy of threatening black clouds, but the thousands of fans who had traveled from throughout New York City to Coney Island to watch the Brooklyn Cyclones play the Williamsport Crosscutters did not seem to mind. The 7,500-seat stadium was about three-quarters full, and when outfielder
title: Ballpark Hums, but Not the Neighborhood; Coney Island, Once a Wonderland of Whimsy, Is Still Waiting for a Rebirth

title: 14 Are Shot, 5 Fatally, Over 10 Hours in Brooklyn and Bronx

title: Estranged Husband Helps Police in Solving Woman's Murder

title: When a Park Turns Into a Soundscape

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Intern Charged In Sex Abuse

body: At an urban crossroads where the going-out-of-business sale has been a perennial marketing tool, what is one to make of the rock band Phish, which has announced its own demise, showing up to perform free? It did so yesterday, standing 20 feet above Broadway on the Ed Sullivan Theater marquee, offering a 45-minute show to a pulsating crowd on the
title: A Band on the Way Out Goes Broadway

body: Phish is breaking up, and you probably don't care. Unless you're a member of that band's large but limited cult, you've probably never seen Phish live. title: Critic's Notebook; Some Small Pleasures, As Phish Dissolves

title: OLYMPICS; Torch Brings Respect for Marbury

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: One Dead And One Hurt In Stabbing

Mr. Inniss, 34, approached a man who appeared to be shoplifting about
title: Stabbing Kills A Store Worker In Coney Island

But this singer and songwriter is Jewish, and quite
title: Vintage Pop Star With the Soul of a Bar Mitzvah Boy

body: IT'S an eerily calm Saturday afternoon, so still that onshore breezes barely stir the parasols of oaks and maples towering above the bungalows. Around this onetime summer haunt, driveways are empty. Clapboard shacks remain shuttered. Lights are off. But there is one exception. In a rust-orange house at the base of a hill, Jerry and Diane Waters
title: 'Poor Man's Paradises': Not Just for Summer

body: THE particulars of the case went something like this. It seemed a man was suffering from a burning on the soles of his feet, caused, a doctor said, by varicose veins. The man, who had lately been talking to anti-radiation activists, was convinced that deadly gamma rays were seeping up through the floorboards of his East Village apartment, and he
title: CITYPEOPLE; Hopeless Causes Esq.

body: WITH the exception of the mayor and a stray actor or two, the subway trains are generally bereft of public figures. It's an anonymous journey. This is not the case on the F train, however, where every day a luminary rides alongside the commuters in the form of a small, sweet-natured old panhandler named Sonny Payne. Sonny has worked the F train so
title: The Ballad Of Sonny Payne

title: NEW YORK BOOKSHELF/BASEBALL; A City Batting Order, Babe Ruth to Ed Hearn

title: BASKETBALL; Telfair Will Skip College For Chance to Join N.B.A.

body: New Yorkers, it seems, will do anything to hold on to a cheap apartment. Even, according to an investigation by the city, bring a relative back from the dead. The city's Department of Investigation announced the arrest of 12 people who were accused of living illegally in New York City public housing for years. The department had been investigating
title: City Arrests 12 in Housing Fraud

author: Andy Newman is a reporter in the Brooklyn Bureau of The New York Times
body: What I love about Brooklyn is that it's impossible to get a handle on. It lacks anything approaching a center of gravity. Picture the combined populations of Atlanta, Boston, Miami, Cleveland and Seattle crammed into a space smaller than Cincinnati but with a downtown only as impressive as, say, that of Hartford, Conn., and you start to get the
title: OUR CORRESPONENT IN BROOKLYN; A Rare And Stirring Mixture

body: Alaska JUNEAU JAZZ AND CLASSICS -- May 21-29. If I lived in Alaska I might demand more from my local summer festival, but then again if I lived in Alaska I might be thrilled that summer had come at all. Alongside classical chamber concerts by local musicians, this festival has some big-name jazz and roots-rock bands, like the Dirty Dozen Brass Band

body: TWO writers who helped define 20th-century New York died within the past 10 days. Hubert Selby Jr., who died last Monday, was best known for his stark novel ''Last Exit to Brooklyn, '' published in 1964 by Grove Press. His prose was all Red Hook, spare, direct, as subtle as a punch in the gut from a heavyweight boxer; he was a high school dropout.
title: NEW YORK WRITERS -- Selby and Hamburger: The Profane, and the Urbane; Jukes, Pimps and the Gowanus

body: FIRST by trade, now by tunnel, he has become bound to the best point guard there is. Stephon Marbury, a man of many moves, will not easily free himself from Jason Kidd. title: Sports of The Times; To Stage Revival, Marbury Needs A Supporting Cast

title: Sports of The Times; A One-Sided Series, Except at Point Guard

title: 5th Graders Are Sent to Hospital After Getting Rash in Brooklyn

title: Shedding Coats And Cares On a Great Day

body: To those who whiz by it on the Belt Parkway, Nellie Bly Amusement Park in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, looks like a mom-and-pop operation. But it isn't. It's only a mom operation. title: Bensonhurst Journal; The Time Has Come to Ride and Beep and Laugh Again

body: Kathy the beluga whale, the ever-smiling ambassador of the New York Aquarium and holder of numerous cetaceous records, was euthanized yesterday at her home in Coney Island, Brooklyn, after a long illness. title: Kathy the Beluga, 34, Is Dead; Brought Smiles, and Gave Them

body: It takes a tough borough to breed a tender fish, Dr. Martin P. Schreibman likes to say. And the roughly 3,000 Brooklyn-bred tilapia Dr. Schreibman grows in tanks in his aquaculture lab grow up hardy and with the requisite dose of attitude. To prove it, Dr. Schreibman, a biology professor at Brooklyn College, grabbed a handful of food pellets the
title: Chasing a Fish-Farming Dream; Brooklyn College Professor Sees a City of Tilapia Tanks

body: A 17-year-old girl fatally stabbed her father on Saturday after he struck her repeatedly with a baseball bat at their Coney Island apartment, the police said yesterday. Dozens of domestic violence incidents had occurred at the apartment since the family moved in about 10 years ago, the police said. The girl was acting in self-defense, the police
title: Girl, 17, Stabs Father to Death In Brooklyn

body: The trouble all started with Shorty's toilet. Shorty -- his nickname, and the only name by which he is willing to be identified -- used to own the largest remaining and least respectable flea market on Surf Avenue, the decaying amusement strip that parallels the Coney Island shoreline. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CONEY ISLAND; A Bedraggled Flea Market Makes Way for Progress

title: Fired Transit Worker Is Held In Killing of 2 Ex-Supervisors

title: 2 Transit Workers Are Found Fatally Shot

author: Thomas Boyle, a professor of English at Brooklyn College, is the author of several crime novels set in Brooklyn.
body: OUT here in Brooklyn, we hear that New Jersey's Nets are coming. This could be great news, but at the same time it brings back the bitter memory of the nasty departure of our baseball Dodgers in 1957. And just over a week ago, Gage & Tollner, our oldest restaurant and most charming culinary relic of the dear departed 19th century (sorry about that,
title: CITY LORE; Put Down That Violin. Now.

author: S.S. Fair writes frequently about music and fashion.
body: Since we are going back to fashion, it's not absurd to wonder what's out of fashion -- the laws of cultural physics state that what's in is defined by and dependent on what's out. One fashion legend who's on the far side of chic these days is the late Romain de Tirtoff, whose initials, if you pronounce them with Parisian flair, are air-TAY, written
title: Tongue And Chic

body: On the day that Mets pitchers and catchers reported to spring training, the first question posed to the team's general manager was about Alex Rodriguez. So was the second question. And even the third. Such is the state of the Mets, who are recognized mostly right now because they do not have Rodriguez and they are not the Yankees. Instead of
title: BASEBALL; Mets Try Not to Dwell on Ones Who Got Away

body: To the Editor: Re ''Beyond Brrr: The Elusive Science of Cold'' (Feb 10): As a member of the Coney Island Polar Bear Club, I applaud the recent efforts to scientifically quantify each person's perception of cold with improved wind chill parameters. Polar bears regularly put physiology, societal norms and individual perception of the weather aside
title: Getting a Hold on Cold

author: Darcy Frey, a frequent contributor to the magazine, is the author of ''The Last Shot: City Streets, Basketball Dreams,'' which is being reissued this month in an updated version.
body: New York hoops fans, especially those who follow the game as it's played on this city's scruffy asphalt courts and playgrounds, have had much to cheer about this winter, with Stephon Marbury, the N.B.A. All-Star and local legend, coming home at 26 as a newly minted Knick and Sebastian Telfair, a nationally ranked 18-year-old phenom, bringing glory
title: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 2-15-04; Betrayed By The Game

body: The shooting of three men in an elevator in a Coney Island housing project on Sunday appeared to be related to both drugs and gangs, the police said yesterday. All three men had criminal records and were shot in the head, suggesting they had been singled out for execution-style killing, a law enforcement official said. One died immediately, and the
title: Police Tie Drugs and Gangs To Killing in Coney Island

body: One man was killed and two others were left in critical condition when gunfire erupted last night in a Coney Island housing project, amid what fellow residents described as rival gang activity and drug sales in the building's corridors. The police said they responded to a 911 call about 7:30 p.m. from someone describing the sounds of multiple gun
title: Man Shot to Death in Coney Island Housing Project

body: After Jesus Colon immigrated to the United States from Puerto Rico in 1917, he worked days and his brother worked nights. The schedule was convenient for a family too poor to afford two pairs of pants. Mr. Colon, who died in 1974 after becoming a writer and political activist, recalled going off to his job every day in clothes that were still warm
title: Toil, Tears and Sweat in Brooklyn

body: WILLIG--Meg, 85 years old, died on February 4th, 2004 after a prolonged struggle to overcome the effects of a cerebral hemorrhage. She is survived by her husband of 65 years, Jack; her son, Robert, and his wife, Ginny; her grandchildren, David, Danny, Jared, Scott, Brent and Alexandra; and her great-grandchildren, Noa and Elai; as well as her
title: Paid Notice: Deaths WILLIG, MEG

body: To the Editor: I enjoyed your Jan. 30 Beijing Journal about winter swimming in China. As a longtime member of the Coney Island Polar Bear Club, however, I must say that the comment ''and not just a once-a-year polar bear plunge for the cameras'' may leave the wrong impression with your readers. The Coney Island Polar Bear Club, in cooperation with
title: The Swimmer in Winter

body: It should not have seemed surprising in a ''one day you're up the next day you're down'' kind of town that the thermometer can prove as fickle as so many other indicators of fortune. But as temperatures pushed into the 40's in New York yesterday, winter game faces gave way to unzipped jackets, ungloved hands and what might seem an unlikely level of
title: New Yorkers, Shaking Off Parkas, Get 43-Degree Weather and Survive

author: Adrian Nicole LeBlanc is the author of ''Random Family: Love, Drugs, Trouble, and Coming of Age in the Bronx,'' which will be published in paperback this month by Scribner.
body: IT seems significant that on one of my first outings to the South Bronx, I couldn't find my way back home. I lived in Chelsea then, and I was still new to New York. I worked days as an editor at Seventeen magazine and did my freelance reporting at night. The Village Voice had assigned me a piece on drug dealers' girlfriends. I borrowed a friend's
title: Uptown Girl

body: At Abraham Lincoln High School in Brooklyn, the bathrooms are so bad that students have been known to use the toilets at Coney Island Hospital, down the road. At the High School for Health Professions and Human Services in Manhattan, leaky bathroom ceilings prompt students to head for McDonald's, or hold out for hours. ''I just try to wait till I
title: Dirty and Broken Bathrooms Make for a Long School Day

body: By Wednesday morning, Bruce C. Ratner had nearly sealed his $300 million offer to buy the Nets and move them to Brooklyn. But nothing was certain, not after a week in which his confidence soared and plummeted as he struggled to outnegotiate a rival. Around 10 o'clock, a fax arrived in Skillman, N.J., at the law office of Edwin Stier, a former
title: PRO BASKETBALL; Ratner's Path To Buy Nets Had Pitfalls And Promise

body: Contrary to popular belief, Brooklyn did not die when a rich man named Walter O'Malley took away the Dodgers after the 1957 baseball season. Brooklyn is still there. From the edge of the South Street Seaport in Manhattan, gazing east, you can see a silhouette of towers, bridges, piers and steeples that would take your breath away if they suddenly
title: Sports of The Times; A New Bounce in Brooklyn's Step

body: Perry McLaughlin, part-time student, longtime Knicks fan, 39-year-old Brooklyn resident, tried to absorb the news as he stood in front of New York City College of Technology in downtown Brooklyn yesterday. The New Jersey Nets had been bought by a man determined to move them to Brooklyn. There was a sense of celebration, yes, but of competing
title: PRO BASKETBALL: THE STREET; Fans in the City Feeling the Tug From a Rivalry

body: UNTIL now, basketball in Brooklyn mostly meant schoolyard courts or the high school gyms where teenagers learned to shoot and pass, to dunk and defend. You could dream about playing for the Knicks at the Garden, but if you had big-time talent, you had to go away to a college out there in the sticks where you knew you would feel like a stranger.
title: Sports of The Times; Brooklyn Crosses Bridge Back Into the Big Time

body: HYMAN--Henry, 86, of Brooklyn, died on January 18, 2004. Loving husband of the late Rachel, devoted brother of Sy and the late Noel, adored uncle and dear friend. A rare human being loved by many, he will be missed by all. Funeral services Yablokoff Chapel, January 20, 1978 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, at 11:00AM. HYMAN -- Henry. Temple Beth El
title: Paid Notice: Deaths HYMAN, HENRY

body: The Bloomberg administration, after a two-year review of the city's property tax laws, has delayed a broad legislative push to overhaul New York City's tax assessment system after concluding such changes would be politically impossible in Albany now. The city Finance Department is still moving ahead with internal changes in how it supervises its
title: City Backs Off Overhaul Effort On Assessments

body: Stephon Marbury's greatest assist on a night of glittering passes that drew gasps and led to quick swishes occurred when he was already on the bench and the Knicks held a 25-point lead with five minutes to play. Thanks to Marbury, the crowd of 18,661 at Madison Square Garden was hailing a coaching legend from Brooklyn, chanting ''Lenny Wilkens.''
title: PRO BASKETBALL; Wilkens and Knicks Hit It Off From the Start

body: The revival of Brooklyn has been painfully slow, an effort eked out neighborhood by neighborhood, with chic new restaurants in Fort Greene, artists' lofts in Williamsburg, new businesses in industrial Red Hook and the transformation of derelict factory buildings into million-dollar condominiums in an area with the unlikely name of Dumbo. But the
title: Yo, Dodgers? No Way! Brooklyn Is Betting on the Nets for Revival

body: Until yesterday, no point guard has made more of an impact on the Knicks in the past two weeks than Isiah Thomas has from his cellphone. Thomas, the Knicks' new president, made a bold call to change that. He delivered a flashy All-Star point guard to the Knicks in Stephon Marbury, whose dream from his Coney Island beginnings has always been to play
title: PRO BASKETBALL; Knicks Bring Marbury Home in Big Trade

body: There is Stephon Marbury's petulant past: four teams in eight years, a litany of disgruntled teammates, most who wanted him to pass first and shoot second, and no second-round playoff experience on the rsum. There is also a brilliant forecast, the raw explosiveness, the way he turns a routine jump-stop into riveting theater, skittering by one
title: PRO BASKETBALL: N.B.A. Analysis; Knicks Could Take Off, If the Baggage Is Gone

body: SHERMAN -- Sol ''Chubby''. Died January 1, 2004. Husband of Frances. Father of Ellen, Brenda, Ava and Rodney. Grandfather of Andrew, Russell, Ian, Beth and Mara. Funeral service on Sunday, January 4, 2004 at 11:30 AM at Weinstein & Garlick Chapel, 1153 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn, NY.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths SHERMAN, SOL ''CHUBBY''
